title: Article on West Indies migration - change

content.description:
“Before the World War there was a large exodus of Negroes from the British West Indiesislands of the Caribbean under British control to Harlem. They came to this Promised Land in steamersteamboat after steamer. These Negroes are well educated and clever and after settling here a while many of them built up prosperous businesses. Today many of them own their own stores and drive about in motor cars.
The newcomers in Harlem...[include] Porto RicanPuerto Rican Negroes.... They are arriving in ever increasing numbers, swelling the Negro population.... They are distinctly of a Spanish type and a...Spanish origin. The signs above shop doors are in Spanish, the books exhibited in store windows are in that language, and the food served in their restaurants is cooked to the Spanish taste.”
Source: “Come From West Indies,” article published in The Northwest Enterprise, newspaper, September 3, 1931
content.question: “The signs above shop doors are in Spanish” describes which of the following changes in Harlem’s Black community?

choices.label: Pan-African schools were established to teach the Black community Spanish.
Afro-Caribbean immigration prompted the Black press to begin publishing newspapers in Spanish.
Afro-Caribbean immigrants increased the linguistic diversity of Harlem’s African American community.
Black business leaders sought financial support from Caribbean governments to stabilize the Black community.

content.answer: Afro-Caribbean immigrants increased the linguistic diversity of Harlem’s African American community.
